name: Original Toll House Chocolate Chip Cookies
name_origin: This is a modern American dish name, not of North African or Judeo-Arabic origin. 'Toll House' refers to the Toll House Inn in Whitman, Massachusetts, where Ruth Wakefield invented the cookie in the 1930s. The Hebrew word 'Ugiyot' (עוגיות) is the plural diminutive of 'Ugah' (cake/bread), derived from Biblical Hebrew (baked round loaf). The rest of the Hebrew name is a direct transliteration of the English 'Chocolate Chips'. Its presence in a Djerban cookbook represents modern culinary globalization rather than traditional heritage.
description: The classic American cookie recipe featuring a buttery dough, semi-sweet chocolate morsels, and nuts. Crispy on the edges and chewy in the center.
cultural_context: While not of North African origin, this American classic has become a staple in many modern Jewish households.
vegan_adaptation_notes: Replace butter with vegan butter or margarine; replace eggs with flax eggs or commercial egg replacer.

ingredients.name: Vegan butter
ingredients.notes: 1 cup / 2 sticks; use high-quality block style

ingredients.name: Flax eggs
ingredients.notes: Mix 2 tbsp ground flaxseed meal with 6 tbsp warm water; let sit 5 mins

steps.instruction: In a small bowl, combine flour, baking soda, and salt; set aside.
In a large mixer bowl, beat butter, granulated sugar, brown sugar, and vanilla extract until creamy. Beat in eggs one at a time.
steps.tips: Ensure butter is softened for best texture.

steps.instruction: Gradually beat in the flour mixture. Stir in semi-sweet chocolate morsels and nuts by hand.
Drop dough by rounded measuring tablespoonfuls onto ungreased cookie sheets.
Bake for 9 to 11 minutes until edges are golden brown. Let stand on cookie sheets for 2 minutes before removing to wire racks to cool completely.
steps.tips: Do not overbake; centers should still look slightly soft.

variants.name: Pan Cookie
variants.description: Bar cookie variation baked in a single pan.
variants.instructions: Preheat oven to 375°F (190°C). Spread dough in a greased 15½ x 10½ x 1-inch baking pan. Bake 20 to 25 minutes. Cool completely before cutting into 2-inch squares.

image.generation_prompt: A close-up, high-resolution shot of a stack of freshly baked vegan chocolate chip cookies resting on a vintage ceramic plate with intricate blue patterns. The cookies are golden brown with crispy edges and soft, chewy centers, featuring generous pools of melted dairy-free semi-sweet chocolate and toasted walnut pieces. The setting is a rustic kitchen in an early 1900s stone house in Safed, illuminated by warm, natural light streaming through an arched window. In the background, blurred details of rough-hewn stone walls and antique copper baking tools create a nostalgic atmosphere. A glass of cold oat milk sits nearby, capturing the essence of a comforting, plant-based afternoon treat in a historic setting.

name_etymology.meaning: Little cakes with chocolate pieces (Toll House style)
name_etymology.notes: Historical record of Ruth Wakefield (1938). This is an outlier in a North African context, likely added to a modern edition of the cookbook for variety.

alternative_names.name: Biscuits aux pépites de chocolat
alternative_names.notes: Common name used in Francophone Tunisia for this imported style

similar_dishes.name: Ghraiba / Ghribia
similar_dishes.similarity: Both are short, buttery tea-time cookies.
similar_dishes.key_difference: Ghraiba uses chickpea or wheat flour and oil/butter for a sandy texture, traditionally without chocolate.

similar_dishes.name: Croquant / Krokan
similar_dishes.similarity: Crispy baked sweet snack often containing nuts.
similar_dishes.key_difference: Croquants are hard, twice-baked almond biscuits (like biscotti), lacking the chewy center and butter content of American cookies.

similar_dishes.name: Boulou
similar_dishes.similarity: Sweet baked good often containing chocolate chunks or nuts.
similar_dishes.key_difference: Boulou is a dry, crunchy roll/biscuit (closer to mandelbrot), while Toll House cookies are rich, buttery drop cookies.

intro_paragraph: Original Toll House Chocolate Chip Cookies are named after the Massachusetts inn where they originated. Known in Hebrew as *ugiyot*, meaning little cakes, this vegan version replaces eggs and dairy while keeping the classic taste. These crispy and chewy treats have become a beloved staple in modern plant-based kitchens.

vegan_substitutions.notes: Maintains the buttery flavor and structure
Ground flaxseed mixed with water provides binding and chewiness
